questions.question: Subsequent events are events that occur:

options.A: During the current fiscal year
options.B: Between the balance sheet date and the date of the auditor's report
options.C: Only after the audit report is issued
options.D: During the planning phase of the audit

questions.explanation: Subsequent events occur after the balance sheet date but before the date of the auditor's report. The auditor has responsibility to identify and evaluate these events for their effect on the financial statements.
questions.tip: Subsequent events period = balance sheet date â†’ auditor's report date.

questions.question: A Type I (recognized) subsequent event is one that:

options.A: Arises from conditions that did not exist at the balance sheet date
options.B: Provides additional evidence about conditions that existed at the balance sheet date
options.C: Only requires disclosure
options.D: Occurs more than 90 days after year-end

questions.explanation: Type I events provide evidence about conditions existing at year-end, such as resolution of a contingency or bankruptcy of a customer whose receivable was already uncollectible. These require adjustment to the financial statements.
questions.tip: Type I = condition existed at year-end. Adjust the financial statements.

questions.question: A Type II (nonrecognized) subsequent event is one that:

options.A: Requires adjustment to the financial statements
options.B: Provides evidence about conditions arising after the balance sheet date
options.C: Is not material and requires no action

questions.explanation: Type II events arise from conditions that occurred after year-end, such as a fire or acquisition. These do not require adjustment but may require disclosure if material to prevent misleading financial statements.
questions.tip: Type II = condition arose after year-end. Disclose if material, don't adjust.

questions.question: Procedures to identify subsequent events include:

options.A: Only reading the subsequent period's financial statements
options.B: Inquiries of management, reading minutes, and reviewing subsequent accounting records
options.C: Confirming all year-end balances
options.D: Testing transactions only through the report date

questions.explanation: Subsequent events procedures include inquiry of management about significant events, reading minutes, reviewing subsequent accounting records, examining cutoff, and obtaining legal counsel responses about litigation.
questions.tip: Procedures: inquiry + read minutes + review records + read legal letters.

questions.question: Which is an example of a Type I subsequent event?

options.A: A major customer files for bankruptcy after year-end, confirming uncollectibility
options.B: A fire destroys a warehouse after year-end
options.C: A new product line is introduced in January
options.D: Declaration of a dividend after year-end

questions.explanation: A customer's post year-end bankruptcy may confirm that the receivable was already impaired at year-end. The condition (customer's financial distress) existed at year-end; the bankruptcy just confirms it.
questions.tip: Customer bankruptcy after year-end usually = Type I. Confirms year-end condition.

questions.question: Which is an example of a Type II subsequent event?

options.A: Settlement of litigation for an amount different from the accrual
options.B: Issuance of stock after year-end
options.C: Collection of a receivable previously written off
options.D: Discovery of a fraud that occurred before year-end

questions.explanation: Stock issuance after year-end is a new event that did not exist at year-end. It may require disclosure but not adjustment. The company's capital structure at year-end was not affected by this future event.
questions.tip: Stock issuance, acquisition, natural disaster after year-end = Type II (disclose if material).

questions.question: Dual dating an audit report is used when:

options.A: The audit is performed by two firms jointly
options.B: A subsequent event occurs after the original report date and the auditor modifies the report
options.C: The financial statements are restated
options.D: The audit spans two fiscal years

questions.explanation: Dual dating (e.g., 'March 15, 20X1, except for Note X, as to which the date is April 2, 20X1') is used when a subsequent event disclosed requires extending the date for that specific matter while limiting responsibility for other events.
questions.tip: Dual date = limits responsibility. Only that specific matter gets the later date.

questions.question: Inquiry of management about subsequent events should cover:

options.A: Only new litigation filed after year-end
options.B: Significant commitments, unusual adjustments, and changes in estimates
options.C: Employee vacation schedules

questions.explanation: Inquiries should cover significant transactions and commitments, unusual adjustments, developments affecting estimates, significant changes in capital structure, and status of items involving subjective judgments.
questions.tip: Ask about: commitments, unusual adjustments, estimate changes, capital changes, judgments.

questions.question: The attorney response letter provides evidence about subsequent events by:

options.A: Guaranteeing no litigation will occur
options.B: Identifying litigation matters that may affect the financial statements
options.C: Providing legal advice to the auditor

questions.explanation: The legal letter identifies pending or threatened litigation, claims, and assessments, including developments after year-end that may require adjustment or disclosure in the financial statements.
questions.tip: Legal letter = identify litigation + subsequent developments affecting accruals/disclosures.

questions.question: The auditor's report should be dated:

options.A: As of the balance sheet date
options.B: No earlier than when sufficient appropriate evidence has been obtained
options.C: 30 days after the balance sheet date
options.D: When the financial statements are filed with the SEC

questions.explanation: The report date should be no earlier than when the auditor has obtained sufficient appropriate evidence, including evidence that the complete financial statements have been prepared and management has taken responsibility.
questions.tip: Report date = when sufficient evidence obtained + F/S complete + management sign-off.

questions.question: A subsequent event that raises substantial doubt about going concern should:

options.A: Be ignored since the condition arose after year-end
options.B: Be evaluated and may require adjustment or emphasis paragraph in the report
options.C: Automatically result in a disclaimer
options.D: Only be disclosed in the management letter

questions.explanation: Subsequent events raising going concern doubts require evaluation. If doubt exists, management must evaluate plans, the auditor assesses adequacy of disclosure, and an emphasis paragraph may be needed regardless of when the condition arose.
questions.tip: Going concern from subsequent event = still evaluate + may modify report.

questions.question: The management representation letter should be dated:

options.A: As of the balance sheet date
options.B: As of the date of the auditor's report
options.C: 30 days before the audit report

questions.explanation: The representation letter should be dated as of the date of the auditor's report, covering representations through that date, including representations about subsequent events.
questions.tip: Rep letter date = report date. Covers through the same date as the report.

questions.question: If facts become known after the audit report is released that existed at the report date, the auditor should:

options.A: Take no action since the report has been issued
options.B: Discuss with management and consider whether the report needs to be revised
options.C: Immediately withdraw the audit report

questions.explanation: The auditor should discuss the matter with management, determine if the financial statements need revision, and if so, consider whether the report should be revised. Procedures depend on whether the statements are revised.
questions.tip: Post-release discovery = discuss with management, consider revision, take appropriate action.

questions.question: When an auditor reissues a report on prior period financial statements, the auditor should:

options.A: Use the original report date without additional procedures
options.B: Consider subsequent events procedures up to the new report date
options.C: Only update the date if requested by management

questions.explanation: When reissuing a report, the auditor should perform subsequent events procedures from the original report date to the new date. Alternatively, the auditor may dual date or use the original date with appropriate disclosure.
questions.tip: Reissuance = subsequent events procedures through new date. Or dual date.

questions.question: A dividend declared after year-end but before the audit report date:

options.A: Should be recorded as a liability at year-end
options.B: Is typically a Type II event requiring disclosure
options.C: Requires restatement of prior years
options.D: Has no accounting or disclosure impact

questions.explanation: A dividend declared after year-end is a Type II event. No liability existed at year-end because the obligation arose after that date. Disclosure may be appropriate but adjustment is not required.
questions.tip: Post year-end dividend = Type II (disclose). No liability at year-end.

questions.question: A natural disaster occurring after year-end that destroys significant assets is:

options.A: A Type I event requiring adjustment
options.B: A Type II event requiring disclosure if material
options.C: Not a subsequent event
options.D: Reason to withdraw the audit opinion

questions.explanation: Natural disasters occurring after year-end are Type II events because the loss did not exist at year-end. Material losses should be disclosed to prevent the financial statements from being misleading.
questions.tip: Post year-end disaster = Type II. Disclose if material, no adjustment needed.

questions.question: Litigation pending at year-end is settled after year-end for significantly more than the recorded accrual. This is:

options.A: Always a Type II event
options.B: Likely a Type I event requiring adjustment to the accrual
options.C: Not relevant to the year-end financial statements

questions.explanation: Settlement of pre-existing litigation provides evidence about conditions at year-end. If the settlement significantly exceeds the accrual, it suggests the accrual was understated and adjustment may be required.
questions.tip: Settlement of existing litigation = Type I. Provides evidence about year-end condition.

questions.question: Reading minutes of board and shareholder meetings after year-end helps identify:

options.A: Only routine matters
options.B: Significant transactions, commitments, and events requiring attention
options.C: Employee vacation schedules

questions.explanation: Board and shareholder minutes may reveal significant transactions, financing arrangements, authorized capital changes, acquisitions, or other events occurring after year-end that require disclosure.
questions.tip: Post year-end minutes = source for identifying significant subsequent events.

questions.question: Review of accounting records after year-end helps identify:

options.A: Only errors in the prior year
options.B: Journal entries and transactions that may indicate events affecting year-end statements
options.C: Budget variances for the current year

questions.explanation: Subsequent accounting records may reveal adjusting entries, significant accruals, or transactions that indicate conditions existing at year-end or events requiring disclosure.
questions.tip: Subsequent accounting records = evidence about year-end conditions and events.

questions.question: Cutoff testing relates to subsequent events by helping to ensure:

options.A: All subsequent events are disclosed
options.B: Transactions are recorded in the correct period
options.C: Management is acting in good faith
options.D: The auditor's report is properly dated

questions.explanation: Cutoff testing ensures transactions occurring around year-end are recorded in the appropriate period. Reviewing subsequent period transactions helps identify items that may have been recorded in the wrong period.
questions.tip: Cutoff testing = transactions in correct period. Part of subsequent events work.

questions.question: A significant debt refinancing after year-end that affects debt classification:

options.A: Requires retroactive adjustment of the year-end balance sheet
options.B: May affect classification of debt as current or noncurrent per GAAP guidance
options.C: Has no impact on year-end financial statements

questions.explanation: Under GAAP, subsequent refinancing may allow classification of short-term debt as long-term at year-end if certain conditions are met. The auditor evaluates whether classification criteria are satisfied.
questions.tip: Subsequent refinancing = may allow long-term classification of short-term debt.

questions.question: A major business acquisition completed after year-end is:

options.A: A Type I event requiring adjustment
options.B: A Type II event that may require disclosure
options.C: Not a subsequent event

questions.explanation: A business combination completed after year-end is a Type II event. The acquired company was not owned at year-end, so no adjustment is made. Disclosure may be required if the acquisition is significant.
questions.tip: Post year-end acquisition = Type II. Disclose if material.

questions.question: A stock split occurring after year-end but before report issuance:

options.A: Requires adjustment of year-end stockholders' equity
options.B: Requires retroactive adjustment of earnings per share
options.C: Has no effect on the financial statements
options.D: Must be disclosed as an uncertainty

questions.explanation: Stock splits occurring before the report is issued require retroactive adjustment of earnings per share for all periods presented, to reflect the change in shares outstanding. This ensures comparability.
questions.tip: Stock split before report = retroactively adjust EPS. Shows per-share data consistently.

questions.question: Documentation of subsequent events procedures should include:

options.A: Only events requiring adjustment
options.B: Procedures performed, dates covered, and conclusions reached
options.C: A list of all events occurring after year-end
options.D: Only negative responses from management inquiry

questions.explanation: Documentation should describe the procedures performed, the period covered by those procedures, any events identified, and the auditor's conclusions about the need for adjustment or disclosure.
questions.tip: Document: procedures + dates covered + findings + conclusions.

questions.question: If after the report is issued the auditor discovers that necessary subsequent events procedures were omitted:

options.A: No action is needed since the report is already issued
options.B: The auditor should assess the importance and consider additional procedures
options.C: The report must be withdrawn immediately

questions.explanation: The auditor should assess whether the omitted procedures are important to supporting the opinion. If so, additional procedures should be performed and the auditor should consider the effect on the audit report.
questions.tip: Omitted procedures = assess importance + consider additional procedures if significant.

questions.question: If management refuses to revise financial statements for a Type I subsequent event requiring adjustment:

options.A: The auditor should accept management's decision
options.B: The auditor should consider modifying the opinion due to material misstatement
options.C: The auditor should disclose the matter in the management letter
options.D: The auditor should wait for the next year's audit

questions.explanation: If management refuses to adjust for a Type I event and the effect is material, the financial statements contain a material misstatement. The auditor should modify the opinion (qualified or adverse).
questions.tip: Management won't adjust Type I = material misstatement = modify opinion.

questions.question: In a quarterly review, the accountant should inquire about events occurring:

options.A: Only during the quarter
options.B: From the date of the financial information to the date of the review report
options.C: Only if management volunteers information

questions.explanation: In a review engagement, the accountant inquires about events subsequent to the date of the interim financial information that may require adjustment or disclosure, through the date of the review report.
questions.tip: Review engagement = subsequent events inquiry too, through report date.

questions.question: When auditing comparative financial statements, subsequent events procedures:

options.A: Only cover the current year
options.B: Should consider events affecting both current and prior year statements
options.C: Are not required for prior years

questions.explanation: Subsequent events may affect both current and prior year financial statements presented for comparison. The auditor considers events that may require adjustment or disclosure in either period presented.
questions.tip: Comparative statements = subsequent events may affect both years presented.

questions.question: For SEC registrants, subsequent events disclosures must be evaluated through:

options.A: The balance sheet date
options.B: The date the financial statements are issued or available to be issued
options.C: 60 days after year-end

questions.explanation: Under GAAP, subsequent events are evaluated through the date financial statements are issued (SEC registrants) or available to be issued (non-public entities). This determines the subsequent events period.
questions.tip: SEC registrants = evaluate through issuance date. Not just report date.

questions.question: Resolution of a contingency after year-end typically:

options.A: Has no effect on year-end statements
options.B: Provides evidence about the contingency's status at year-end
options.C: Requires a change in accounting principle

questions.explanation: Resolution of a contingency (like settlement or court verdict) after year-end provides evidence about conditions that existed at year-end. The resolution helps determine whether the year-end accrual was appropriate.
questions.tip: Contingency resolution = evidence about year-end condition. Affects year-end accrual evaluation.

questions.question: A major restructuring announced after year-end:

options.A: Always requires adjustment to year-end statements
options.B: May require disclosure but typically not adjustment unless committed to before year-end
options.C: Has no impact on the audit
options.D: Requires restatement of all prior periods

questions.explanation: Restructuring announced after year-end is typically Type II unless management was committed to a plan before year-end meeting recognition criteria. Material restructurings should be disclosed.
questions.tip: Post year-end restructuring = usually Type II. Committed before year-end = may be Type I.

questions.question: Discovery after year-end that the prior year financial statements contain a material error:

options.A: Is handled only in next year's audit
options.B: May require revision of the prior period statements if they will be reissued
options.C: Has no effect on current year procedures

questions.explanation: Material errors in prior periods discovered subsequently should be corrected. If prior statements will be reissued (in comparative statements), they should be revised. The error affects the current audit's opening balances.
questions.tip: Prior period error = correct if material. Affects comparative statements.

questions.question: Significant inventory write-downs occurring in the subsequent period:

options.A: Never affect year-end valuation
options.B: May indicate that net realizable value was below cost at year-end
options.C: Only require current year recognition

questions.explanation: Subsequent period write-downs may indicate inventory was already impaired at year-end. If evidence suggests NRV was below cost at year-end, adjustment may be required as a Type I event.
questions.tip: Subsequent inventory write-down = was NRV already below cost at year-end?

questions.question: The auditor has an active duty to search for subsequent events:

options.A: Indefinitely after the report date
options.B: From year-end to the report date
options.C: Only during fieldwork

questions.explanation: The auditor has an active responsibility to perform subsequent events procedures from the balance sheet date to the report date. After the report date, responsibility is passive (respond to facts that come to attention).
questions.tip: Active duty = year-end to report date. After report date = only respond if facts arise.

questions.question: When previously audited financial statements are included in a securities registration statement:

options.A: The auditor has no further responsibilities
options.B: The auditor should perform certain subsequent events procedures up to the effective date
options.C: Only the underwriter is responsible for subsequent events
options.D: The original report date controls all responsibilities

questions.explanation: When financials are included in a registration statement, the auditor performs subsequent events procedures up to the effective date (or as close as practical) and may need to update the audit report.
questions.tip: Registration statement = subsequent events through effective date. Extended responsibility.
